title: Going out of your lane... Is it the right call?
body:
Is it always a bad thing during laning? I know mid does it a lot and no one cares, but I'm sure that comes from it happening at the pro level or something. There seems to be a consensus that whatever happens there is supposed to happen, and whatever happens in normal play isn't, so if I had to guess...

Anyway, a scenario from my last game: I'm playing Taric with Teleport and Exhaust. Don't ask why, it's a long explanation that makes me seem like more of a hardcore gamer than I really am. The point is that I was running Teleport, not Flash.

At about the 12 minute mark, our jungler got caught around dragon and we went to back him up. As I went to go back to bot after the skirmish, I noticed a teleport going in from the other side right near our low Ekko. So being nearby, I ran to assist. Things happened, Ekko survived and had to back. I checked bot. Not a soul present, so I figured I'd hold mid for Ekko until he got back.

Six seconds later, a fight breaks out 2v2 top, and Kat goes to engage. I ping my team away but they're ignoring it, so I follow to back them up. Eventually one fight ends but rolls right into another, and then that fight rolls into another. Now I'm up there with Shen trying to keep Yasuo and Katarina off of him long enough for me to go back to bot and him to go back period, because he's quite low at this point.

"taric", Shen says between dodges. What does he want? Impossible to tell from that, so I start looking for pings. Maybe he wants me to go on one of the two opponents tightening the noose on him. At this point Shen decides to take the time to stop under tower and nearly get caught by Yasuo's Q to say "retard taric", and later "go bot".

Aha. So he's... pissed that I'm trying to help him survive what would otherwise be a 2v1, and that every time I've ducked into the bush to leave, either he's nearly been killed or I've been followed and chased out. He continues every chance he gets. "taric. noob to bot"

Now Ekko chimes in, slinging mud at me and asking why I'm not bot. Of course I can't explain at this point because we're skirmishing constantly. But rest assured, the _second_ Kat goes back to her own lane, I get into the bush, teleport bot, and keep Lucian from dying to a Cait Q. All is well.

That's a long setup, but all that to say, the situation made me wonder. Was I really in the wrong? Is it ever okay for a support to leave their lane? Effective teamplay in any game is about strategy, and the man who literally wrote the book on strategy is Sun Tzu. He states that no plan is absolute, and that the ability to adapt to any situation, often in orthodox ways, is the key to gaining victory. But what do you think? Maybe I'm a League illiterate.

I could have run away and left Shen to die. He probably would've cursed me for it, too. And for good reason if you ask me. Their Mastery 7 Yasuo was already 2/0 with an edge on CS, and he'd have another kill or assist with the better part of a minute to free farm. We won the game, by the way, and I wound up with a 6:1 assist-to-death ratio. So I don't think that one play hurt my capacity to support all that much in the long run.

First: I wanna know the reason for Ex+TP. Sounds interesting.

Second: Always explain what you're doing to your team. A simple "I'm making sure they aren't able to tower dive you so you can recall" is enough.

   I'm (was, now I main mid) a jungler and found out that you have to treat your team as a bunch of toddlers if you want any manner of teamwork to be shown. "Hey, I'm going to invade Udyr's jungle. Can you back me up if things go wrong, Ahri?" And only go if they give you a clear answer. I'm not sure of your rank, but playing through many different accounts I've found out that up until gold people are just as stupid as in bronze. Hell, even some plats manage to be complete idiots when it comes to map awareness and team plays.

Pasted from my reply to another comment:

As a Japanese gamer, I've gotten used to avoiding what my senpai calls "foreigner's crutches". There are a lot of features in foreign games that Japanese gamers find to be too easy, and won't use because they think it will make them worse players in the long run. Flash is one of those, because you start to feel like you can make stupid decisions as long as you have a flash to get you out of trouble. Or like you don't have to fight too hard when you engage because you can always Flash-Ignite. (Ignite is another by the way.)

So I have a choice. As a support, I basically have two valid options for replacing it: Teleport or Heal. Since Heal's effect is reduced each time it's used within a short span, I've found Teleport is more useful, as it allows me to do things like this: Help out lanes that are struggling, then quickly port back to bot. Nevermind that I can take the 2-for-1 trades if my teleport is up and not miss out on too much gold.

> Second: Always explain what you're doing to your team. A simple "I'm making sure they aren't able to tower dive you so you can recall" is enough.
> 

Oh absolutely. When I finally got a chance to breathe and get back bot, I explained, but they didn't seem to accept it. Oh well. To be fair, it _was_ a while before I could explain.

Yeah staying with shen was good. Lucian can easily evaporate waves and ekko can force tower while you help handle his laner.

You were in the right. A ***good*** support doesn't just stay bot all game. If the rest of the map has issues, or you can get another lane snowballing with a drive by support gank, then do it. Lucian is really good at playing safely in lane, so he can survive without a support constantly tied to him. Just gotta judge the situation, your team, and see what would help the most.

The support is not just for the ADC. The support helps the entire team. ^^

Good, this is what I've always thought too. :) It's one reason I run Teleport. If this weren't the case, I'd bring Heal and Exhaust.
I've also run into players who don't understand that support helps the entire team, not just bot lane. Don't take it personally at all.

It doesn't matter what lane I'm currently in, be it a main role or even support.

 If the chance to help another lane arrives, and it doesn't hinder your own laning abilities, I don't see the harm in trying to help. It is, after all, a team game. Capitalizing off each other is something that is relatively needed to win, push, or even get a head by the slightest. As a mid/support main, I tend to roam a lot with pinging my team or explaining. It helps a lot and can potentially put you and your team mates ahead.

Some people don't like it, however. I've supported some ADCs that hate when their support leave lane, even if we were ahead. It's just something you need to figure out with and around your team. It's a good strategy but you need to keep your team in the loop.

Pro supports roam all the time. Just like roaming from another lane or ganking you have to know how to do it properly.

You don't seem to understand that taking TP exh makes your lane weaker as support. Also, you don't get that once you leave your lane the way you are doing, you are giving up a third of the map. Even if you are winning your lane; all that pressure is lost.

If you want to help your team (you are focusing on this too much); the best thing to do is dominate your opposing matchup then extending your lead to help your team that way.

Here's where you should start until you get better at understanding the game. Force the enemy to back early through trades, crash your wave into turret and back. This simple practice will get you up in xp and gold over your opponents.

If it's a matter of helping me not die, I'd honestly rather keep my mind trained to not overextend, rather than subconsciously getting myself thinking it's okay to do so because I can just Flash out.

And I understand the lack of pressure for sure. Trust me, I don't just decide on a whim "oh, our lane is pushed, let's TP top and see what I can do" lol. I take teleport specifically to allow me to roam mid if bot is strong and mid is struggling, and then TP back as soon as the momentum starts to shift. (At least as far as laning phase goes.) In this case, ending up top was purely a matter of shifting circumstances and adaptation, and no one was in bot until the last minute or so of my roaming period. We never really lost ground; in fact, I'm pretty sure our bot never lost a tower all game.

> If you want to help your team (you are focusing on this too much); the best thing to do is dominate your opposing matchup then extending your lead to help your team that way.

At this point in the game I reference, my Lucian was something like 4/1 with about a 30 CS advantage. Lucian is pretty good and keeping waves clear, so that was never a fear.
